elements.content: A series of anion complexes of the 4-pyridyl-functionalized tripodal tris(urea) receptor (L) have been synthesized. Ligand L forms the 1:1 anion complex [Cl⊂L]− with various metal chloride salts, MCl x (M = Na, K, Mg, Ca, Mn, Co, x = 1 or 2). When M = Na, K, Mg, and Ca, the metal ions are not coordinated by the pyridyl groups of L but are involved in second-sphere coordination to form three-dimensional structures. However, in the complex of Co2+, the transition metal ions are directly coordinated by the pyridyl groups. Interestingly, the Mn2+ ion forms two complexes with both of the above two types of structure. In all complexes, one chloride ion is “half” encapsulated in the cleft of one ligand by N–H···Cl hydrogen bonds to form the [Cl⊂L] units, which are further linked via intermolecular interactions into three-dimensional structures. Moreover, the fluoride and carbonate complexes of L have also been obtained. The solution anion binding properties of L have been studied by 1H NMR spectroscopy and electrospray ionization mass spectrometry.

In all complexes, one chloride ion is "half" encapsulated in the cleft of one ligand by N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl hydrogen bonds to form the [Cl⊂L] units, which are further linked via intermolecular interactions into three-dimensional structures. Moreover, the fluoride and carbonate complexes of L have also been obtained. The solution anion binding properties of L have been studied by 1H NMR spectroscopy and electrospray ionization mass spectrometry.

The countercation either participates in the second-sphere coordination (M = Na, K, Mg, Ca, Mn) or coordinates directly to the pyridyl groups (M = Mn, Co).

elements.content: Since Park and Simmons discovered in 1968 that katapinands can encapsulate a chloride ion, which was structurally confirmed in 1975, the supramolecular chemistry of anions has attracted much attention because of the relevance of anions in chemistry, biology, and environmental events. The chloride ion plays pivotal roles in biological processes, for example, in signal transduction or transport of organic solutes through the cell membrane. A number of cyclic and acyclic hosts, such as triazolophanes or aryl-triazole systems, macrobicyclic and macrotricyclic amines, octaaminocryptands, and oligoureas, have been reported to show very high binding affinities for halide species.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since Park and Simmons discovered in 1968 that katapinands can encapsulate a chloride ion, which was structurally confirmed in 1975, the supramolecular chemistry of anions has attracted much attention because of the relevance of anions in chemistry, biology, and environmental events. The chloride ion plays pivotal roles in biological processes, for example, in signal transduction or transport of organic solutes through the cell membrane. A number of cyclic and acyclic hosts, such as triazolophanes or aryl-triazole systems, macrobicyclic and macrotricyclic amines, octaaminocryptands, and oligoureas, have been reported to show very high binding affinities for halide species.

elements.content: The tris(2-aminoethyl)amine moiety was first introduced into the framework of anion hosts by Reinhoudt and co-workers. This tripodal structure has proven to be a promising scaffold for anion binding due to its favorable conformation for multiple hydrogen bonds, and many tren-based receptors with a variety of anion-binding sites such as amine, amide, urea, and thiourea groups, etc. have been synthesized. Such receptors not only can complementarily encapsulate oxoanions (sulfate, carbonate, and phosphate) but also display excellent binding abilities to the spherical halide ions. For instance, Beer et al. reported that a tripodal tris(amido-benzo-15-crown-5) ligand can cooperatively bind chloride, iodide, or perrhenate anions, while Fabbrizzi et al. studied the incipient and definitive proton transfer of urea-fluoride interaction with tripodal ligands. In addition, Das et al. discussed the binding of halides and oxoanions by a protonated tris(amide) receptor, and Ghosh et al. reported a pentafluorophenyl-substituted tripodal amine receptor that encapsulates a Cl– or Br– ion within the cleft upon protonation of the secondary amines. Furthermore, the encapsulation of Cl– ion by a tris(amide) analogue was also reported. Very recently, Gale et al. reported the effects of fluorination of tris(thio)urea receptors on the transmembrane transport of chloride through a lipid bilayer.

For instance, Beer et al. reported that a tripodal tris(amido-benzo-15-crown-5) ligand can cooperatively bind chloride, iodide, or perrhenate anions, while Fabbrizzi et al. studied the incipient and definitive proton transfer of urea-fluoride interaction with tripodal ligands. In addition, Das et al. discussed the binding of halides and oxoanions by a protonated tris(amide) receptor, and Ghosh et al. reported a pentafluorophenyl-substituted tripodal amine receptor that encapsulates a Cl- or Br- ion within the cleft upon protonation of the secondary amines. Furthermore, the encapsulation of Cl- ion by a tris(amide) analogue was also reported. Very recently, Gale et al. reported the effects of fluorination of tris(thio)urea receptors on the transmembrane transport of chloride through a lipid bilayer.

elements.content: Our recent research has focused on anion coordination by urea-based receptors. The 3-pyridyl-substituted tripodal tris(urea) (L3‑py) has been synthesized, which can selectively encapsulate sulfate ion by one or two receptor molecules. Furthermore, we have modified the tripodal tris(urea) with the redox-active ferrocenyl groups as electrochemical reporting units (LFc), as well as with quinolinyl groups (LQn) or Ru(bipy)3 moieties for the fluorescent signaling purposes. It is noticeable that, although the terminal 3-pyridyl groups in the ligand L3‑py (or the 4-pyridyl analogue L) are potentially metal coordination sites, they do not coordinate to any transition metal (Mn2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Co2+) or Mg2+ ions in the capsular sulfate complexes; instead, the metal ions exist as the hydrated [M(H2O)6]2+ form and interact with the ligand in the second coordination sphere. Similarly, in the sulfate complexes of L3‑py with the alkali metal Li+, Na+, and K+ ions, these metal ions also interact with the pyridine N groups through the hydrated [Li2(H2O)2]2+, [Na(H2O)4]2+, and [K2(H2O)2]2+ units, respectively.

Furthermore, we have modified the tripodal tris(urea) with the redox-active ferrocenyl groups as electrochemical reporting units (LFc), as well as with quinolinyl groups (LQn) or Ru(bipy)3 moieties for the fluorescent signaling purposes. It is noticeable that, although the terminal 3-pyridyl groups in the ligand L3-py (or the 4-pyridyl analogue L) are potentially metal coordination sites, they do not coordinate to any transition metal (Mn2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Co2+) or Mg2+ ions in the capsular sulfate complexes; instead, the metal ions exist as the hydrated [M(H2O)6]2+ form and interact with the ligand in the second coordination sphere. Similarly, in the sulfate complexes of L3-py with the alkali metal Li+, Na+, and K+ ions, these metal ions also interact with the pyridine N groups through the hydrated [Li2(H2O)2]2+, [Na(H2O)4]2+, and [K2(H2O)2]2+ units, respectively.

elements.content: In the current work, we report the anion binding properties of the 4-pyridyl-substituted tripodal tris(urea) L (Scheme ). The receptor readily forms the 1:1 anion complex with a series of metal chloride salts MCl x (M = Na, K, Mg, Ca, Mn, Co; x = 1 or 2), in which the chloride ion is encapsulated in the tripodal cleft of the ligand. Interestingly, in the manganese and cobalt complexes, the 4-pyridyl groups of L directly coordinate to the metal ion, forming the octahedral [M(N)6]2+ metal complexes besides the anionic [Cl⊂L] “half capsule”, which is significantly different from the 3-pyridyl substituted receptor (L3‑py). Moreover, the fluoride complex shows a similar 1:1 structure, while the carbonate ion (CO3 2–) is encapsulated in the 2:1 (host to guest) fashion as in the case of the sulfate ion. The anion binding of L in solution was also studied by 1H NMR spectroscopy.

Moreover, the fluoride complex shows a similar 1:1 structure, while the carbonate ion (CO3 2-) is encapsulated in the 2:1 (host to guest) fashion as in the case of the sulfate ion. elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of Ligand L

elements.content: The receptor L was synthesized from the reaction of pyridyl isocyanate with tris(2-aminoethyl) amine (molar ratio 3:1) under a nitrogen atmosphere. The binding of L with various chloride salts was tested, and crystals of seven chloride complexes (1–6) were obtained by slow diffusion of diethyl ether into the CH3OH/H2O solution of the ligand and an equimolar amount of NaCl, KCl, MgCl2·6H2O, CaCl2, MnCl2·4H2O, or CoCl2·6H2O. X-ray diffraction and elemental analysis revealed the compositions of complexes 1–6 to be M(H2O)3[Cl⊂L] (M = Na, 1; K, 2), M(H2O)6[Cl⊂L]2 (M = Mg, 3; Ca, 4; Mn, 5A) and M[Cl⊂L]2, (M = Mn, 5B; Co, 6), respectively. The main structure of these anion complexes is similar, characterized by a [Cl⊂L]− “half capsule” in which a chloride ion is encapsulated by the three arms of one tripodal ligand. All of the NH groups point to the inside of the cleft and form N–H···Cl hydrogen bonds with the Cl– ion (N···Cl distances range from 3.1 to 3.6 Å and N–H···Cl angles from 143° to 167°; ). These compounds are only sparingly soluble in methanol and DMSO and are insoluble in other common organic solvents.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and Crystal Structures

The receptor L was synthesized from the reaction of pyridyl isocyanate with tris(2-aminoethyl) amine (molar ratio 3:1) under a nitrogen atmosphere. The binding of L with various chloride salts was tested, and crystals of seven chloride complexes (1-6) were obtained by slow diffusion of diethyl ether into the CH3OH/H2O solution of the ligand and an equimolar amount of NaCl, KCl, MgCl2⋅6H2O, CaCl2, MnCl2⋅4H2O, or CoCl2⋅6H2O. X-ray diffraction and elemental analysis revealed the compositions of complexes 1-6 to be M(H2O)3[Cl⊂L] (M = Na, 1; K, 2), M(H2O)6[Cl⊂L]2 (M = Mg, 3; Ca, 4; Mn, 5A) and M[Cl⊂L]2, (M = Mn, 5B; Co, 6), respectively. The main structure of these anion complexes is similar, characterized by a [Cl⊂L]- "half capsule" in which a chloride ion is encapsulated by the three arms of one tripodal ligand. All of the NH groups point to the inside of the cleft and form N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl hydrogen bonds with the Cl- ion (N⋅⋅⋅Cl distances range from 3.1 to 3.6 Å and N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl angles from 143° to 167°; ). These compounds are only sparingly soluble in methanol and DMSO and are insoluble in other common organic solvents.

elements.content: Interestingly, the countercation has minimum effects on the chloride-encapsulating [Cl⊂L] moiety but greatly alters the whole structure of the complexes, which can be categorized to three isomorphous groups: 1 and 2 (Pa3̅); 3, 4, and 5A (R3̅); and 5B and 6 (P3̅). In these structures, the coordination environment of the metal cations, either the alkali and alkaline earth metals or transition metals, is significantly different, thus leading to interesting aggregations of the cationic units and anionic capsules as discussed below. It should be noted that the manganese complexes 5A and 5B were isolated from the same tube, but they have significantly different unit cell parameters and structures (vide infra). The negative-ion mode electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) spectra of these complexes () display anionic peaks at m/z 541.2 for [L + Cl]−, which further prove the 1:1 binding of chloride ion in solution.

In these structures, the coordination environment of the metal cations, either the alkali and alkaline earth metals or transition metals, is significantly different, thus leading to interesting aggregations of the cationic units and anionic capsules as discussed below. It should be noted that the manganese complexes 5A and 5B were isolated from the same tube, but they have significantly different unit cell parameters and structures (vide infra). The negative-ion mode electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) spectra of these complexes () display anionic peaks at m/z 541.2 for [L + Cl]-, which further prove the 1:1 binding of chloride ion in solution.

elements.content: In addition, we have also studied the coordination of L with other anions, and the complex with another halide F–, K(H2O)3[F⊂L] (7), as well as two complexes of carbonate, M2(H2O)4[CO3⊂L 2] (M = Na, 8; K, 9), were isolated. The fluoride complex 7 is isomorphous to complexes 1 and 2 (space group Pa3̅) (). The complexes with CO3 2– ion (8 and 9) show the typical capsular structure in which two inversion-symmetric L molecules encapsulate a carbonate anion, as in the case of the sulfate encapsulation.

The fluoride complex 7 is isomorphous to complexes 1 and 2 (space group Pa3̅) (). The complexes with CO3 2- ion (8 and 9) show the typical capsular structure in which two inversion-symmetric L molecules encapsulate a carbonate anion, as in the case of the sulfate encapsulation.

elements.content: The complexes 1 and 2 comprise of anionic [Cl⊂L]2 2– and cationic [M2(H2O)6]2+ subunits interconnected by hydrogen bonds into a three-dimensional framework. In the anionic “half capsule” [Cl⊂L]− (Figure a), there are six hydrogen bonds between the encapsulated Cl– ion and urea NH protons. Notably, two [Cl⊂L] units dimerize in a staggered manner to form a “full capsule” containing two ligands and two anions (Figure b). Correspondingly, the alkali metal ions (Na+, K+) are also paired up by six bridging water molecules to form the [M2(H2O)6] dimer. Each alkali metal ion is further coordinated by three direct M–O bonds to the carbonyl groups of the ligand (Figure c,d). Thus, the Na+ or K+ ions are essentially nine-coordinate. Moreover, the [M2(H2O)6] dimer contacts with six pyridyl N donors in the secondary coordination sphere through 12 N···H–Ow hydrogen bonds (Figure d).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of Complexes M(H2O)3[Cl⊂L] (M = Na, 1; K, 2)

The complexes 1 and 2 comprise of anionic [Cl⊂L]2 2- and cationic [M2(H2O)6]2+ subunits interconnected by hydrogen bonds into a three-dimensional framework. In the anionic "half capsule" [Cl⊂L]- (Figure a), there are six hydrogen bonds between the encapsulated Cl- ion and urea NH protons. Notably, two [Cl⊂L] units dimerize in a staggered manner to form a "full capsule" containing two ligands and two anions (Figure b). Correspondingly, the alkali metal ions (Na+, K+) are also paired up by six bridging water molecules to form the [M2(H2O)6] dimer. Each alkali metal ion is further coordinated by three direct M-O bonds to the carbonyl groups of the ligand (Figure c,d). Thus, the Na+ or K+ ions are essentially nine-coordinate. Moreover, the [M2(H2O)6] dimer contacts with six pyridyl N donors in the secondary coordination sphere through 12 N⋅⋅⋅H-Ow hydrogen bonds (Figure d).

elements.content: Each [Cl⊂L]2 2– capsule is surrounded by six M2(H2O)6 dimers, which are arranged in a pseudo-octahedral geometry (Figure c). The anion–cation aggregation in 1 and 2 is different from the sulfate complexes of L3‑py and L, in which the M(H2O)6 2+ cation provides six chelating water molecules, forming a three-dimensional framework with octahedral connectivity. It is also different from the clusters Na2(H2O)4 2+ and K2(H2O)2 2+ in the sulfate complexes of L3‑py. In the former case of sodium ion, the cationic Na2(H2O)4 2+ unit provides four water hydrogen-bond donors, and the two Na+ cations are linked by two hydrogen-bonded water dimers, whereas in the latter compound two K+ ions are bridged by two water molecules and the clusters act as pseudo-octahedral 6-connecting nodes linking six pyridylurea chelating groups.
elements.clean_text: Each [Cl⊂L]2 2- capsule is surrounded by six M2(H2O)6 dimers, which are arranged in a pseudo-octahedral geometry (Figure c). The anion-cation aggregation in 1 and 2 is different from the sulfate complexes of L3-py and L, in which the M(H2O)6 2+ cation provides six chelating water molecules, forming a three-dimensional framework with octahedral connectivity. It is also different from the clusters Na2(H2O)4 2+ and K2(H2O)2 2+ in the sulfate complexes of L3-py. In the former case of sodium ion, the cationic Na2(H2O)4 2+ unit provides four water hydrogen-bond donors, and the two Na+ cations are linked by two hydrogen-bonded water dimers, whereas in the latter compound two K+ ions are bridged by two water molecules and the clusters act as pseudo-octahedral 6-connecting nodes linking six pyridylurea chelating groups.

elements.content: Crystal structure of 1. (a) Molecular structure of the [Cl⊂L]− anion complex showing the encapsulation of a chloride ion in L by six N–H···Cl hydrogen bonds. (b) The [Cl⊂L]2 2– dimer. (c) Pseudo-octahedral arrangement of six [Na2(H2O)6]2+ clusters around the [Cl⊂L]2 2– capsule. (d) Coordination environment of [Na2(H2O)6]2+ unit showing the six bridging water molecules between two Na+ ions and the interaction of Na+ ion with urea carbonyl groups.

elements.content: The crystal structures of some chloride complexes of tripodal ligands have been reported recently. The triply protonated pentafluorobenzyl-substituted tris(amine) receptor can encapsulate one of the three halide counterions inside the tripodal cavity, while the tripodal hexaamide receptor encapsulates Cl– ion in its cleft through three hydrogen bonds. However, for the protonated 3,5-dinitrobenzoyl-based tris(amide) receptor, the Cl– ion is not encapsulated in the cleft but interacts with the amide functionality of each side arm. Theoretical studies have also been carried out, which reveal that the p-cyanophenyl-based tripodal tris(urea) receptor can include Cl– ion inside the cavity by six N–H···Cl interactions. Recently, Gale et al. reported the tris-urea and -thiourea receptors with fluorinated aryl groups, which encapsulate Cl– ion by six N–H···Cl hydrogen bonds (3.200(2)–3.600(2) Å) similar to the complexes in the present work. These results demonstrate the ability of tripodal receptors to bind chloride ions in different environments.

However, for the protonated 3,5-dinitrobenzoyl-based tris(amide) receptor, the Cl- ion is not encapsulated in the cleft but interacts with the amide functionality of each side arm. Theoretical studies have also been carried out, which reveal that the p-cyanophenyl-based tripodal tris(urea) receptor can include Cl- ion inside the cavity by six N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl interactions. Recently, Gale et al. reported the tris-urea and -thiourea receptors with fluorinated aryl groups, which encapsulate Cl- ion by six N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl hydrogen bonds (3.200(2)-3.600(2) Å) similar to the complexes in the present work. elements.content: Complexes 3, 4, and 5A with the divalent alkaline earth metal (Mg2+ and Ca2+) or transition metal (Mn2+) cations are isomorphous. Like in 1 and 2, two chloride “half capsules” are dimerized, and each chloride is bonded by three urea groups through six hydrogen bonds. This aggregation of two [Cl⊂L] units is similar to the sulfate- and phosphate-encapsulating complexes. For example, Das et al. reported that two tris(urea) receptor molecules can pack in a face-to-face fashion with an encapsulated sulfate-(H2O)3-sulfate adduct. Ghosh et al. reported the [H2PO4]2 2– dimer encapsulation by the pentafluorophenyl-substituted tripodal tris(urea) via hydrogen bonding and anion···π interactions. In complexes 3–5A, the two half capsules have a separation of 11.22–11.33 Å between the two bridgehead N atoms () and a Cl···Cl separation of 3.44–3.46 Å.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of Complexes M(H2O)6[Cl⊂L]2, (M = Mg, 3; Ca, 4; Mn, 5A)

Complexes 3, 4, and 5A with the divalent alkaline earth metal (Mg2+ and Ca2+) or transition metal (Mn2+) cations are isomorphous. Like in 1 and 2, two chloride "half capsules" are dimerized, and each chloride is bonded by three urea groups through six hydrogen bonds. This aggregation of two [Cl⊂L] units is similar to the sulfate- and phosphate-encapsulating complexes. For example, Das et al. reported that two tris(urea) receptor molecules can pack in a face-to-face fashion with an encapsulated sulfate-(H2O)3-sulfate adduct. Ghosh et al. reported the [H2PO4]2 2- dimer encapsulation by the pentafluorophenyl-substituted tripodal tris(urea) via hydrogen bonding and anion⋅⋅⋅π interactions. In complexes 3-5A, the two half capsules have a separation of 11.22-11.33 Å between the two bridgehead N atoms () and a Cl⋅⋅⋅Cl separation of 3.44-3.46 Å.

elements.content: As in the sulfate complexes of L and the analogous ligand L3‑py, the metal ions (Mg2+, Ca2+, Mn2+) in 3, 4, and 5A are not coordinated by the pyridine N donors of ligand L but exist as the hexahydrated [M(H2O)6]2+ units around the [Cl⊂L]2 2– cage. The hydrated cations are involved in second-sphere coordination with the 4-pyridyl or carbonyl groups of the ligand through O–Hw···N (2.782 Å) and O–Hw···O (2.839 Å) hydrogen bonding. Each [Cl⊂L]2 2– cage is located at the center of an octahedron formed by six [M(H2O)6]2+ cations (Figure a), whereas each [M(H2O)6]2+ cation is also surrounded by an octahedron formed by six [Cl⊂L]2 2– moieties (Figure b). Such an arrangement leads to a three-dimensional NaCl-type structure, which is essentially the same as in the case of the 2:1 sulfate complexes, whose [SO4⊂L 2]2– components are replaced by [Cl⊂L]2 2– in the chloride complexes 3–5A. It is worth noting that, unlike the sulfate complex of L3‑py, in which the full capsule was fixed by the same H2O molecule of the [M(H2O)6]2+ unit, in complexes 3–5A each capsule is linked by two different H2O molecules of the [M(H2O)6]2+ unit through a pyridyl group and a urea CO from another ligand (Figure c). In other words, each water molecule of the [M(H2O)6]2+ unit interacts with the urea CO and pyridyl N from two different capsules.

elements.content: Notably, yellow prism crystals of another manganese chloride complex with the composition Mn(N)6[Cl⊂L]2 (5B) were isolated from the same tube where the light-yellow cubic crystals of 5A were obtained. Complex 5B and the cobalt(II) analogue 6 show isomorphous structure. Different from complexes 1–5A, the chloride ion is bound by three stronger (N–H···Cl < 3.5 Å) and three weaker (3.5 < N–H···Cl < 3.6 Å) hydrogen bonds. The most striking feature of the structure is that the transition metal ions are directly coordinated by the pyridyl groups of the ligand. Each Mn or Co atom is surrounded by six pyridyl N atoms from six different ligand molecules in an octahedral coordination environment (Figure ) with M–N distances of 2.3048(3) Å (M = Mn, 5B) and 2.2161(2) Å (M = Co, 6), respectively.

elements.content: The crystal structure of the fluoride complex 7 is very similar to the chloride analogues M(H2O)3[Cl⊂L] (M = Na, 1; K, 2). The fluoride ion is “half” encapsulated in the cleft of the ligand through six N–H···F hydrogen bonds (N···F, 2.85–3.17 Å; ∠N–H···F, 146–161°; Figure a). The potassium ions are also paired up by six bridging water molecules to form the [K2(H2O)6] dimer and interact with L through the CO and pyridine nitrogen atoms. Compared to the chloride complex 2 (with same countercation), the smaller fluoride ion leads to a more contracted capsule (the size of the dimerized “full capsule” in 7 is smaller than the chloride analogue 2; distance between the two bridgehead N atoms: 11.07 versus 11.25 Å; Figure ). Similar fluoride encapsulation was reported for a tripodal tris(ferrocenylurea) and a pentafluorophenyl-substituted tris(urea) receptor. The hydrogen-bond lengths in 7 (mean N···F: 3.012 Å) are slightly longer than those in these reported compounds (2.834 and 2.814 Å, respectively) and the N–H···F angles are comparable (154°, 149° and 153°, respectively).

elements.content: The complexes [M2(H2O)4]·[CO3⊂L 2] were obtained by slow diffusion of diethyl ether into a CH3OH/H2O solution of ligand L and Na2CO3 or K2CO3. The complexes crystallized in the triclinic P1̅ space group. In the structure, one carbonate ion is encapsulated by two ligands to form the full capsule. It should be noted that the crystal-imposed inversion symmetry caused partial distribution of the three oxygen atoms of CO3 2– to four positions with 0.75 occupancy each, forming a rhombus (Figure ), which is similar to the carbonate complex of a bisurea ligand reported previously by us.

The complexes [M2(H2O)4]⋅[CO3⊂L 2] were obtained by slow diffusion of diethyl ether into a CH3OH/H2O solution of ligand L and Na2CO3 or K2CO3. elements.content: In complex 8, the two L molecules are orientated in a face-to-face fashion with a distance of 9.88 Å between the bridgehead nitrogen atoms (), leading to a centrosymmetric molecular capsule. The carbonate ion is surrounded by six urea groups by multiple N–H···O hydrogen bonds. Like in the related sulfate complexes, there are stronger and weaker N–H···O contacts in the range of N···O distances <3.2 Å and <3.5 Å, respectively (). However, in complex 9, 12 stronger hydrogen bonds are formed (N···O distances <3.2 Å). On changing the cations from Na+ to K+ in complexes 8 and 9, the size of the capsule varies from 9.96 Å to 9.88 Å, indicating the effects of the countercation in tuning the size of the complex. Carbonate binding by tripodal tris(urea) ligands has previously been reported by Custelcean and Das. The L3‑py ligand formed a three-dimensional framework of the [CO3⊂L2] capsules linked by Mg(H2O)6 2+ cations acting as hydrogen-bonding bridges. In the case of the nitrophenyl (m- or p-) functionalized tripodal urea receptor, the CO3 2– anion was originated from atmospheric CO2.

elements.content: In spite of the slightly different hydrogen bond modes of the anion, the coordination sphere of the external cations (Na+ or K+) is almost the same for 8 and 9. Different from the clusters K2(H2O)2 2+ in the sulfate complex of L3‑py, there is an extra terminal water molecule in 8 and 9. Two alkali metals (Na+ or K+) are bridged by two water molecules, and each M+ ion is further coordinated by two 4-pyridyl groups, one urea carbonyl group, and a terminal water (Figure c). Thus, the Na+ or K+ ions are essentially six-coordinate. Meanwhile, the terminal and bridging water molecules are further hydrogen bonded to urea or pyridyl groups (). The packing diagram of the compound viewed down the c-axis is depicted in Figure d.

elements.content: A comparison of the structures of complexes 1–7 is worthwhile. In all of the three structure types, a chloride or fluoride ion is encapsulated in the cleft of one ligand, which is in contrast to the 2:1 encapsulation of sulfate and phosphate ion. In the first two groups of complexes, such half capsules are dimerized to form a dinuclear “full capsule”. Most interestingly, in complexes 5B and 6, the 4-pyridyl donors coordinate to the metal ions directly, which is significantly different from the sulfate complexes of the same metal ions with the 3-pyridyl analogue L3‑py. This difference might be attributed to the smaller steric hindrance of the 4-pyridyl terminals than the 3-pyridyls. The external countercations may increase the rigidity of the structure by multiple hydrogen bonding interactions, but they do not show much influence on the anion capsule (the size of the “full capsule” of 1–5A is in the range of 11.18–11.33 Å, and that of the fluoride complex 7 is 11.07 Å, respectively; ). Notably, we have also attempted to crystallize the chloride complexes of L3‑py with a series of MCl x salts; unfortunately, no products have been isolated so far.

Notably, we have also attempted to crystallize the chloride complexes of L3-py with a series of MCl x  salts; unfortunately, no products have been isolated so far.

elements.content: The anion complexes were further characterized by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements. The experimental PXRD patterns of 1–9 are consistent with the simulated ones from the single crystal structures (), confirming the phase purity of these anion complexes. In addition, their TGA curves display similar two-step weight losses () except for complexes 5B and 6, which are attributable to the loss of the coordinated H2O molecules (weight loss 5.2–10.8%, calcd 5.8–8.9%) in the 63–204 °C temperature region followed by a small plateau and then decomposition of the complex. Complexes 5B and 6 decompose at 231 and 224 °C directly.

elements.content: The solution binding properties of receptor L with various anions were studied by 1H NMR spectroscopy in DMSO-d 6 (). In the presence of 1.0 equiv of Cl– ions (as [n-Bu4N]+ salt), the urea NH protons displayed slight downfield shifts (Δδ NHa = 0.26, NHb = 0.37 ppm), while addition of Br–, I–, NO3 –, and ClO4 – resulted in almost no change. 1H NMR spectra of the chloride complexes 1–4 in DMSO-d 6 are shown in . The binding behavior of L with sulfate ion has been reported previously, which is similar to the analogous receptor L3‑py.
elements.clean_text:
Anion Binding Studies in Solution

The solution binding properties of receptor L with various anions were studied by 1H NMR spectroscopy in DMSO-d 6 (). In the presence of 1.0 equiv of Cl- ions (as [n-Bu4N]+ salt), the urea NH protons displayed slight downfield shifts (Δδ NHa = 0.26, NHb = 0.37 ppm), while addition of Br-, I-, NO3 -, and ClO4 - resulted in almost no change. 1H NMR spectra of the chloride complexes 1-4 in DMSO-d 6 are shown in . The binding behavior of L with sulfate ion has been reported previously, which is similar to the analogous receptor L3-py.

elements.content: Detailed 1H NMR titration was carried out for the chloride ion (0–10 equiv). The NH signals shifted to the downfield gradually with the addition of increasing amounts of Cl– ions at room temperature (Figure a), indicating the hydrogen bonding interactions of the receptor to the anion. The changes of NH chemical shifts of the ligand showed the best fit for the 1:1 binding mode (Figure b), which was further verified by the Job’s plot (). The Cl– binding constant (log K = 3.05 M–1) was obtained by fitting the 1H NMR titration data with the WinEQNMR program (). This binding constant is similar to the p-cyanophenyl substituted tripodal tris(urea) receptor (log K = 3.09 M–1 for Cl–) but is stronger than the [H3L′]3+ and [H3L″]3+ (L′ and L″ are pentafluorophenyl and phenyl substituted tripodal triamine) with log K values of 2.56 and 1.80 M–1, respectively. Moreover, Gale et al. also observed moderate binding strength (K a ≈ 102 M–1) of tripodal tris(urea) ligands to chloride in the 1:1 complexation.

elements.content: The binding of the related L3‑py ligand toward Cl– anion was also tested. 1H NMR experiments with (n-Bu4N)Cl were carried out under the same conditions employed for L. When 1.0 equiv of Cl– ions were titrated to the solution of L3‑py, the NH signals moved downfield, showing the interaction between L3‑py and Cl–. The titration () demonstrates the 1:1 binding stoichiometry with similar changes of the chemical shifts of NH protons (Δδ NHa = 0.22, NHb = 0.34 ppm), and the binding constant (log K = 3.2 M–1) () of L3‑py is also comparable to that of L.

elements.content: The binding behavior of L with the F– anion (as [n-Bu4N]+ salt) in solution was studied. Addition of the fluoride anion (up to 0.6 equiv) caused obvious broadening of the NH proton signals (Figure a), which became sharp again when 0.8 equiv of fluoride ions were added. The spectrum reached saturation with 1.0 equiv of F–, suggesting a 1:1 binding mode that was also confirmed by the Job’s plot (), with log K = 4.38 M–1 (). Compared to the chloride ion, the larger change of NH chemical shifts (Δδ 0.90 and 1.79 ppm) and the binding constant all reveal stronger affinity of L to fluoride. The binding constant toward fluoride is slightly larger than the pentafluorophenyl-substituted tripodal urea receptor (log K = 4.06 M–1) and nitrophenyl functionalized tripodal urea receptor (p-isomer, log K = 3.72 M–1; o-isomer, log K = 3.45 M–1; m-isomer, log K = 3.87 M–1).

elements.content: The chloride binding of the 4-pyridyl-functionalized tripodal tris(urea) receptor (L) has been discussed. The neutral receptor forms the 1:1 anion complex [Cl⊂L] with various metal chloride salts MCl x (M = Na, K, Mg, Ca, Mn, Co, x = 1 or 2), in which a Cl– ion is encapsulated in the cleft of the receptor by N–H···Cl hydrogen bonds. Notably, the countercations have little effect on the “half capsule” but can lead to significantly different packing structure of the entire compounds. In one case, the alkali metals (Na+, K+), alkaline earth metals (Mg2+, Ca2+), and transition metals (Mn2+) do not participate direct coordination to the 4-pyridyl groups but exist as M(H2O)3 or M(H2O)6 units and interact with the [Cl⊂L] capsule through the secondary coordination sphere. In the other case, remarkably, the transition metal ions (Mn2+, Co2+) are coordinated directly by the pyridyl N atoms in an octahedral geometry. The fluoride complex is isomorphous to the chloride analogues, while the carbonate complexes show the full encapsulation as in the sulfate complexes with tripodal receptors. 1H NMR and ESI-MS analyses revealed the binding of L with chloride anion in solution.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The chloride binding of the 4-pyridyl-functionalized tripodal tris(urea) receptor (L) has been discussed. The neutral receptor forms the 1:1 anion complex [Cl⊂L] with various metal chloride salts MCl x  (M = Na, K, Mg, Ca, Mn, Co, x = 1 or 2), in which a Cl- ion is encapsulated in the cleft of the receptor by N-H⋅⋅⋅Cl hydrogen bonds. Notably, the countercations have little effect on the "half capsule" but can lead to significantly different packing structure of the entire compounds. In one case, the alkali metals (Na+, K+), alkaline earth metals (Mg2+, Ca2+), and transition metals (Mn2+) do not participate direct coordination to the 4-pyridyl groups but exist as M(H2O)3 or M(H2O)6 units and interact with the [Cl⊂L] capsule through the secondary coordination sphere. In the other case, remarkably, the transition metal ions (Mn2+, Co2+) are coordinated directly by the pyridyl N atoms in an octahedral geometry. The fluoride complex is isomorphous to the chloride analogues, while the carbonate complexes show the full encapsulation as in the sulfate complexes with tripodal receptors. 1H NMR and ESI-MS analyses revealed the binding of L with chloride anion in solution.

elements.content: 1H and 13C NMR spectra were measured with a Varian unity INOVA-400 spectrometer with calibration against the solvent signal (DMSO-d 6: δ = 2.50 ppm for 1H NMR) or tetramethylsilane (TMS). Elemental analyses were done on a VarioEL III elemental analyzer. Melting points were detected on an X-4 Digital Vision MP Instrument. ESI-MS measurements were performed on a MALDI-TOF mass spectrometer. TGA were carried out in N2 stream using a Netzsch TG209F3 equipment at a heating rate of 5 °C/min. PXRD data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα, 1.5418 Å).

Synthesis of Anion Complexes 1-9

elements.content: Diffraction data for complexes 1–9 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer at room temperature (292 K) with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Empirical absorption correction by using SADABS was applied for all data. The structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by full-matrix least-squares on F 2. Hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon and nitrogen atoms were included in idealized geometric positions with thermal parameters equivalent to 1.2 times those of the atom to which they were attached. Crystallographic data and refinement details for compounds 1–9 are given in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structure Determination

Diffraction data for complexes 1-9 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer at room temperature (292 K) with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Empirical absorption correction by using SADABS was applied for all data. The structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by full-matrix least-squares on F 2. Hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon and nitrogen atoms were included in idealized geometric positions with thermal parameters equivalent to 1.2 times those of the atom to which they were attached. Crystallographic data and refinement details for compounds 1-9 are given in .

cln_elements.content: A methanol solution (1 mL) of L (25.2 mg, 0.05 mmol) and an aqueous solution (0.25 mL) of anion as different salts (0.05 mmol) were mixed, and the trace precipitate was removed by filtration. Slow diffusion of diethyl ether into the filtrate for several days afforded crystals of complexes 1–9.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Anion Complexes 1-9 

A methanol solution (1 mL) of L (25.2 mg, 0.05 mmol) and an aqueous solution (0.25 mL) of anion as different salts (0.05 mmol) were mixed, and the trace precipitate was removed by filtration. Slow diffusion of diethyl ether into the filtrate for several days afforded crystals of complexes 1-9.

cln_elements.content:
The anion complexes were further characterized by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) measurements. The experimental PXRD patterns of 1–9 are consistent with the simulated ones from the single crystal structures (), confirming the phase purity of these anion complexes. In addition, their TGA curves display similar two-step weight losses () except for complexes 5B and 6, which are attributable to the loss of the coordinated H2O molecules (weight loss 5.2–10.8%, calcd 5.8–8.9%) in the 63–204 °C temperature region followed by a small plateau and then decomposition of the complex. Complexes 5B and 6 decompose at 231 and 224 °C directly.

[Co][Cl⊂L]2 (6)

Pink crystals were obtained after two weeks. Crystal yield: 21 mg, 34%. M.p.: 224 °C (decomp.). Anal. Calcd for C48H60Cl2CoN20O6: C 50.44, H 5.29, N 24.51; found: C 50.42, H 5.26, N 24.48.

[K(H2O)3][F⊂L] (7)

Colorless crystals. Crystal yield: 15 mg, 48%. M.p.: 182 °C. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 400 MHz, ppm): δ 2.45 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 6H, H1), 3.12 (m, 6H, H2), 7.24 (s, NHa), 7.35 (d, J = 4.8 Hz, 3H, H3), 8.17 (d, J = 4.8 Hz, 3H, H4), 10.77 (s, 3H, NHb). Anal. Calcd for C24H30FKN10O6: C 47.02, H 4.93, N 22.86; found: C 46.85, H 4.96, N 22.73.

[Na2(H2O)4][CO3⊂L 2] (8)

Colorless crystals. Crystal yield: 12 mg, 39%. M.p.: 198 °C. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 400 MHz, ppm): δ 2.08 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 6H, H1), 2.86 (m, 6H, H2), 9.48 (s, NHa), 7.35 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 3H, H3), 7.75 (d, J = 5.4 Hz, 3H, H4), 11.65 (s, 3H, NHb). Anal. Calcd for C24.5H34N10NaO7: C 48.72, H 5.66, N 23.21; found: C 48.85, H 5.69, N 23.09.

[K2(H2O)4][CO3⊂L 2] (9)

Colorless crystals. Crystal yield: 15 mg, 44%. M.p.: 204 °C. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, 400 MHz, ppm): δ 2.11 (t, J = 6.2 Hz, 6H, H1), 2.85 (m, 6H, H2), 9.45 (s, NHa), 7.32 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 3H, H3), 7.78 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 3H, H4), 11.62 (s, 3H, NHb). Anal. Calcd for C24.5H34N10KO7: C 47.51, H 5.53, N 22.61; found: C 47.39, H 5.51, N 22.58.
